quoteFirst: Indecent language is allowed to be indulged in during the continuance of this jolly occasion. At
quoteLast: on the full moon day, the image of Holika is burnt, and children sit round the embers, and beat their mouths, making a mock mourning sound. Tender children are swung over the fire for a second by the fond mothers, and this is believed to remove all kinds of danger from the babies.
title: Castes and Tribes of Southern India. Vol. 4 of 7
author: Thurston, Edgar, 1855-1935; Rangachari, K. [Contributor]

quoteFirst: Night.  The Empress sits alone, and the clock ticks,
quoteLast: . The clock nicks off the edges of her life.  She is chipped like an old bit of china; she is frayed like a garment of last year's wearing.
title: Men, Women and Ghosts
author: Lowell, Amy, 1874-1925

quoteLast: they left us; The sweet birds out of our breasts Went flying away in the morning: Will they come again to their nests?
title: Poems

quoteLast: the men got up and bustled about. Their limbs were wellnigh frozen stiff.
title: She's All the World to Me
author: Caine, Hall, Sir, 1853-1931

quoteLast: ; a beautiful starlight night, with no moon, and so not very light. The sea was as calm as a pond, just a gentle heave as the boat dipped up and down in the swell; an ideal night, except for the bitter cold, for anyone who had to be out in the middle of the Atlantic ocean in an open boat. And if ever there was a time when such a night was needed, surely it was now, with hundreds of people, mostly women and children, afloat hundreds of miles from land.
title: Sinking of the Titanic and Great Sea Disasters
author: Marshall, Logan, 1884-1937 [Editor]

quoteFirst: “The Steppy, you know. She surely is a queer one. You just ought to hear her pass remarks,
quoteLast: in the lower hall with the mezzanine floor lined with listening ladies! What the girls don’t guess isn’t worth considering. Guessing is their one strong line. But I like Jack, you know, Gloria, and I’m not catty enough to join in the slaughter.
title: Gloria at Boarding School
author: Garis, Lilian, 1873-1954

quoteFirst: "Don't you worry," he said. "They only thought it was some
quoteLast: of the girls. And it was the truth, wasn't it? What a frightened little thing it is! You'd be scared by your own shadow!"
title: Nell, of Shorne Mills
author: Garvice, Charles, 1850-1920
